text: What's the name for something like `(+)(1,2)` , i.e. wrapping a function in `()` . I didn't see it in the functions portion of the docs. Can someone point me to a resource?

elements.text: What's the name for something like
. I didn't see it in the functions portion of the docs. Can someone point me to a resource?

text: Can we cross post this publicly to <https://discourse.julialang.org|Discourse> for further visibility? React with :bridge: on the message above to approve. <https://github.com/JuliaCommunity/SlackBridge/blob/main/README.md#faq|More info here>

that's just a syntax quark that if your function is a operator you need to do that.
```julia> f(x) = x^2
f (generic function with 1 method)

julia> f(2)
4

julia> (f)(2)
4```
you can do it with any function

text: Note that it's not actually needed here, but it's sometimes useful to disambiguate

elements.text: Note that it's not actually needed here, but it's sometimes useful to disambiguate

text: Thanks for the replies. I think I'm just not sure if this exists for a specific reason, or if it's just for syntax reasons

elements.text: Thanks for the replies. I think I'm just not sure if this exists for a specific reason, or if it's just for syntax reasons

text:
I think syntax like `(X)` is just X in any case. Sometimes you need `()` for syntax reason for example when you do:
```@distributed (+) for ....```
you won't need `()` if your function name is not a binary operator (which creates ambiguity in parsing)
